Examples: "CSV file containing gene expression data for breast cancer"

Description: The overall design of the dataset or file.
The url of where the file is stored.
The assay the file is representative of.
The processing level the file can be mapped to.
Examples: Level 3: Processed summary data, like gene expression counts or coverage statistics (e.g., CSV files)

Description: The species the data was collected on. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
The tumor type(s), if applicable, of the data collected. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
Tissue type(s) associated with the file. Multiple values permitted, comma separated.
The denormalized manifest for file submission.
A unique primary key that enables record updates using schematic.
A label that can be used to identify groups of files from the same longitudinal/time-resolved experiment
The type of event associated with collection of the data contained in the file (e.g., time increment, treatment time elapsed)
Examples: A valid value for 'File Longitudinal Event Type' might be "FileCreated", "FileModified", "FileDeleted", or "FileRenamed".

Description: The order in which this file was collected with respect to the longitudinal experiment (e.g., 1, 2, etc.). Integer.
The unit of time associated with Sequential and Total Time Elapsed attributes.
The time elapsed between collecting the current and previous files in this longitudinal group.
The total time elapsed between the first and current files contained this longitudinal group.
The format of the file described by this entry.
A string identifier associated with the file. Must be unique. Can be the repository accesssion number (e.g., Synapse ID, GEO identifier such as GSE12345). No Greek Letters or DOIs.
